questions.question: What is the most common malignancy of the GI tract?
Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy?

options.D: A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps

questions.explanation: Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy.Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecturethroughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lackcytological features of dysplasia.

questions.question: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectalcancer?
questions.explanation: Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectalcancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of30 years.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of polyps necessary for the diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires ≥100 polyps. The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of the below: • Germline mutation in the APC gene • ≥100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition) • Any colorectal adenomas < 30 years in a patient with a family history of FAP • Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FAP. Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before the age of 30 years and nearly always by the age of 50 years. Attenuated FAP is a less severe form of FAP with the following features: • Usually <100 adenomas • First appear usually in late childhood • Adenomas usually ≤1 cm until adulthood • Adenomas are fewer and later • Adenomas and carcinomas are 60-75% right-sided • The mean age of carcinoma is 55 years.

questions.question: Indirect ophthalmoscopy of an infant revealed congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. This is seen as an extraintestinal manifestation in association with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Classic FAP and Gardner's syndrome are associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hypertrophy. Congenital hypertrophy of the RPE can be generally detected at birth and is, therefore, an adjunct to the early screening of FAP.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?

options.A: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
options.B: Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
options.C: There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
options.D: It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11

questions.explanation: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome. It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11. It is characterized by: • Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation • Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine cancer). Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hairloss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. Onendoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward adiagnosis of Cronkhite-Canada syndrome.It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years.Clinical features include:• Diarrhea and abdominal pain• Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation• Cachexia and anemia•Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due toabnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa

questions.question: Which of the following acts as the initiating mutation in the majority of sporadic coloncancers?1051
questions.explanation: The majority of sporadic colon tumors typically include loss of function mutation ofAPC gene, early in the neoplastic process (the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence).About 10-15% of sporadic colon cancers involve the microsatellite instability pathway, which isassociated with DNA mismatch repair defects (Lynch syndrome).

questions.question: A 70-year-old man with hematochezia and weight loss is diagnosed with colorectal cancer.Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this condition?
questions.explanation: The two most important prognostic factors of colorectal cancer are the depth of invasion and thepresence of lymph node metastases.The liver is the most common site of metastasis from the colon due to its portal drainage.

questions.question: A 52-year-old lady has just been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. On taking a history, she revealed that both her mother and her elder sister had been diagnosed with synchronous colorectal and endometrial cancer in their forties. She should be tested for mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome. She should be tested for mutations in MSH genes. It occurs due to defective DNA mismatch repair. It is caused by inherited mutations in genes that encode proteins responsible for the detection, excision, and repair of errors that occur during DNA replication. They include MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 or EPCAM genes. It is the most common syndromic cause of colon cancer. It tends to occur at younger ages than sporadic colon cancers and often involves the right colon. Familial clustering of cancers occurs at several sites, including: colorectum, small bowel, and stomach; endometrium and ovary; ureters; brain; hepatobiliary tract and pancreas; and skin.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about tumors of the appendix?

options.A: The most common tumor is carcinoid
options.C: Goblet cell variant of carcinoid is more aggressive
options.D: Peritoneal dissemination can result in pseudomyxoma peritonei

questions.explanation: Primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix is usually of mucinous type. Peritoneal dissemination of mucinous tumors can cause pseudomyxoma peritonei. The most common tumor of the appendix is carcinoid tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix. Goblet cell variant of carcinoid tumor is more aggressive.
